subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Quickscript in the NYTimes?
msgSnippet: Alex, there have been a variety of Hebrew scripts in simultaneous use at least since the time the Babylonian and Jerusalem Talmuds were written, c1-3 century
messageBody:
Alex, there have been a variety of Hebrew scripts in simultaneous use at
least since the time the Babylonian and Jerusalem Talmuds were written,
c1-3 century AD (or CE). It was a little bit before this that the
familiar "square" letters became standard, but during the time of the
Talmuds, an alternate letter style, now called the "Rashi" script
came into being. In the Talmud, it is used for emphasis and to set text
apart, as we do with italic letters. It looks kind of like a gentle
rounding of the square letters, but it can be confusing, because
sometimes a Rashi letter looks more like a completely different square
letter than its own square counterpart. I imagine the cursive letters
probably came into use about this time as a faster way of writing
letters, with still rounder shapes.

What is surprising to me, is that at this time, both Aramaic and Arabic
were using mostly connected letters, but even handwritten Hebrew always
keeps the letters disjunct.

Jon

Alexander Lampros wrote:

> kick fucking ass. Hmmm....anyone know when cursive
> Hebrew was devoloped? Has it existed for ever and a
> day, or is it something that was devoloped by the
> Israeli state in 1946?
> Yours,
>
> Alex
>
>
